mortality.note: Tang census: 52.9 million (754 CE) to 16.9 million (764 CE). Actual deaths debated - some fled, some uncounted. Even conservative estimates make this one of history's deadliest conflicts. Deaths from warfare, famine, disease, and displacement. Both rebel and loyalist forces committed atrocities.

rationales.systematic_intensity: Civil war rather than targeted extermination. Both sides committed massacres. Cities changed hands multiple times with accompanying slaughter. But no ethnic or religious targeting - violence was political/military.
rationales.profit: Rebels sought imperial treasury and tax revenues. Soldiers on both sides looted extensively. War economy developed. Land seizures widespread.
rationales.ideology: An Lushan claimed imperial mandate, established Yan Dynasty. But ideology was thin - primarily power grab. No ethnic purification or utopian vision.
rationales.complicity: Regional warlords chose sides opportunistically. Foreign mercenaries (Uyghurs, Arabs) joined for plunder. Population suffered regardless of which side controlled territory.

analysis.pattern_note: Possibly deadliest civil war in human history. Tang Dynasty census shows 36 million population drop - even accounting for refugees and census failures, mortality was catastrophic. An Lushan was a Sogdian-Turkic general who exploited Tang military structure. After his assassination, war continued under successors. Tang never recovered its golden age power. Shows how military-political fragmentation can kill more than ideological genocides. Largely unknown in West despite scale exceeding most European conflicts combined.
warning_signs: Central government losing control of armies
analysis.root_causes: Tang military decentralization, An Lushan's personal ambition, Emperor Xuanzong's complacency, frontier army system (jiedushi), court factionalism
